in-person seminar or other discussion format

Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

comments: We had a weekly blog/discussion post.
n/a

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how to think and write critically about Ulysses and Omeros. I also learned how to effectively engage with peers in discussion seminars.
Great exposure to scholarly criticism. High level of engagement and student discussion
Context on and analysis of Ulysses, Omeros, epics, novels, and postcolonial literature

I learned how to analyze and critically engage with literature that contained foreign/unfamiliar subject matters and material, which really pushed me to open my mind and consider the different values and pressures that were present within the material we read.

James Joyce and Derek Walcott are two writers certainly worth reading. I learned a lot about just how to read difficult works. Moreover, thanks to the amount of secondary readings, I got a good idea about criticism and surrounding philosophy and thoughts. Due to the nature of the works, the questions and discussions we had forced us to think beyond literary phenomena and actually address questions like what it means to navigate a colonial history, what it means for a work to be difficult, what it means to be an "epic." I certainly gained a lot from this course.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Prof. Cleary is the best professor I had at Yale. Sometimes writing weekly discussion posts felt like a lot of work, but there were no "real" weaknesses to this course!
This was a great class -- very well-designed and superbly facilitated. No ideas for improvement.
Perhaps smaller discussion sections once a week would have been helpful

Strengths: Professor Cleary is incredible, the discussion questions always keep us engaged, and the critical readings enrich our understanding of the primary texts. 

Weaknesses: I would have appreciated more integration of our discussions of the two primary texts. I also think our discussions of Omeros felt a little less enthusiastic than our discussions of Ulysses, but maybe we were just tired at the end of the semester.
Amazing course, but I just wish that the seminar was shorter because it took a lot out of me to stay engaged during a 2-hour virtual discussion.
This is an excellent course.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Seminars were amazing and I looked forward to them every week. Not much could be improved.
Was surprised that this two hour seminar worked so well over zoom. Engaging the whole time
I was glad Professor Cleary did not attempt meaningless experiments with technology. The class worked best as a simple Zoom discussion without breakout rooms. We had no problem staying engaged.
Virtual Seminar worked very well.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: YES. YES TO ANY COURSE TAUGHT BY JOE CLEARY! You won't regret it! Do it now!!!
Yes -- provided you want to read Ulysses.
Yes! Wonderful way to read these two difficult works

This is among the best courses I've taken at Yale. Ulysses is a monster of a book, but it was incredibly rewarding to approach it together as a class. I would not have found the novel as personally meaningful if I had read it on my own. The critical readings helped me identify new interests within English literature. Although students were enrolled in the class from many different places, we felt like a community by the end of the semester. This course is a uniquely enriching reading experience!
Absolutely.   Professor Cleary was incredible and really helped facilitate the process of reading such lengthy, dense material.

These works are perhaps unlike other works one has encountered in the literary canon. They are worth reading as they force us to grapple with questions we might not grapple with so often and their styles are highly interesting. Both works are innovative, comic, beautiful, challenging, and certainly epic.
